pullRequest.body:
Add the definition of the ordinary hypergeometric series, and show that its radius is one. Part of this requires an additional theorem about ascPochhammer, which is found in the Pochhammer file. Closely follows the exponential series definition.

#15966

---

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR

Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

will be invisible to reviewers.

I intend to PR the commented inline theorem in Pochhammer after the subsequent build after this is merged, in order to limit the scope of this PR
@EdwardWatine Note that this is currently failing CI! I will wait to review again until it is ready.

One other high level comment as I look at the material in this PR and the similar API for the exponential series is that we should probably introduce a definition:
```lean
def FormalMultilinearSeries.ofScalars (c : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ùïÇ) : FormalMultilinearSeries ùïÇ ùî∏ ùî∏ :=
  fun n ‚Ü¶ c n ‚Ä¢ ContinuousMultilinearMap.mkPiAlgebraFin ùïÇ n ùî∏
```
and develop some API for that. I think it would simplify the work here.

Whoops, I keep forgetting to restart the file after changing the other one...
I agree with adding some more support for scalar Multilinear series, perhaps this could be extended to multiple types of maps and not just MkPiAlgebraFin?

> I agree with adding some more support for scalar Multilinear series, perhaps this could be extended to multiple types of maps and not just MkPiAlgebraFin?

I think `MkPiAlgebraFin` is special enough to deserve it's own dedicated API. If you have the appetite to write this as part of this PR and use it to implement the work here then that would be great. If not, I'm also OK with leaving things are they are for now and I'll do one final round of review after you've had a chance to react to my latest round of nitpicks.

I was having a look for adding API as you suggest, but I'm not entirely sure where it would lie. Ideally it would go in Mathlib\Analysis\Calculus\FormalMultilinearSeries.lean, but we really want to be able to use other results that come from other files such as Mathlib\Analysis\Analytic\Basic.lean and Mathlib\Analysis\NormedSpace\Multilinear\Basic.lean (I think). Perhaps this needs a new file?

> I was having a look for adding API as you suggest, but I'm not entirely sure where it would lie. [...] Perhaps this needs a new file?

Yes I think a new file would be the right move. Maybe `Mathlib.Analysis.Analytic.ScalarSeries` or `Mathlib.Analysis.Analytic.OfScalars` or ...

Thanks :tada:

Thanks for all of this!

Please apply the remaining suggestions and then feel free to merge üéâ 

bors d+

Thanks again for this: it looks great, and not far from being ready to merge.

I'll have a look again when you've had a chance to react to my review so far.
Looking great, a few more nitpicks below:

Thanks for all of this!

Please apply the remaining suggestions and then feel free to merge üéâ 

bors d+

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

```suggestion
/- If the `n`-th Pochhammer function is evaluated at a sufficiently large non-postive integer, then it is
zero.

 Specifically, "sufficiently large" means any integer between `1 - n` and `0`. -/
```

I would be inclined to rewrite this as
```suggestion
    (hnk : ‚àÉ kn : ‚Ñ§, 1 - n ‚â§ k ‚àß kn ‚â§ 0 ‚àß k = kn) : (ascPochhammer R n).eval k = 0 := by
```
Can I get a sense of why you prefer it? I understand rewriting the inequality, but to me, limiting kn to a non-positive integer makes sense directly after the existential binder of kn.

Of course I'm not the author of the suggestion but one point is that except for certain very specific situations, we avoid using `>` and `‚â•` and instead use `<` and `‚â§`. This reduces the need for rewrites.

(Aside: speaking of rewrites, I notice that elsewhere you're using the long-form `rewrite` tactic: we always use `rw` instead.)

Another point I notice here is that it's usually unhelpful to pass a raw existential as hypothesis: instead just demand the data that demonstrates it is true. Finally I would probably just use a natural number rather than non-positive integer. With all these in mind, I'd state this lemma as:
```lean
theorem ascPochhammer_eval_neg_coe_nat_of_lt {R : Type u} [Ring R] {n k : ‚Ñï} (h : k < n) :
    (ascPochhammer R n).eval (-(k : R)) = 0 := by
```
As a final remark, I'd like to say that I'm delighted to see, and very grateful for, this PR! I have a backlog of work and review at the moment so I will have to wait till the weekend to give thorough review.

Thanks for the feedback, I'll replace `rewrite` with `rw`, flip the inequalities and expand the existential as you say. I'm slightly unconvinced by the use of a natural in the way you do, what do you think of this?
```lean
theorem ascPochhammer_eval_neg_coe_nat_of_lt {R : Type u} [Ring R] {n k : ‚Ñï} {r : R} (hr : r = -‚Üëk) 
    (h : k < n) : (ascPochhammer R n).eval r = 0 := by sorry
```
The problem with the goal having `-(k : R)` in the result is that it becomes awkward to manipulate expressions that aren't in that exact form (and you can't use `rw`), whereas taking it into a hypothesis allows delaying it by easily moving it into a goal. I'm sure this situation must come up a lot in Mathlib, so I don't know what the best practice is, but it feels clunky to work with otherwise.

The hypothesis `hr` is of the form `x = f y` for some function `f`. To use a such a lemma you must have (or be able to construct) the equation `x = f y` and so you should just rewrite your goal before calling the lemma. Otherwise we have a less general lemma and potentially need to write lemmas for many functions `f`.

So I still think the form I proposed is the way to go.
Alright, this will need a bit of refactoring then üòÅ

```suggestion
For an integral domain `S`, we show that the
```

Optional:
```suggestion
/- The Pochhammer polynomial of degree `n` has roots at `0`, `-1`, ..., `-(n - 1)`. -/
```
What you have is of course perfectly correct, but I find this slightly easier to understand.

```suggestion
  | zero => contradiction
```

What you have is perfectly good, but fairly low-level. How about:
```suggestion
    rcases lt_trichotomy k n with hkn | rfl | hkn
    ¬∑ simp [ih hkn]
    ¬∑ simp
    ¬∑ omega
```
Ah this is clever! I do like explicit proofs where it helps make things clear, however I like yours better.

Let's call this `k` for consistency elsewhere:
```suggestion
    (n : ‚Ñï) (r : R) : (ascPochhammer R n).eval r = 0 ‚Üî ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñï, k = -r ‚àß k < n := by
```

For a ring `R`, `[NeZero (1 : R)]` is equivalent to `Nontrivial R` (which is preferred) but since you're also demanding no zero divisors, this is actually just saying `R` is an integral domain. So we should drop the `FieldLike` section, and spell this as follows:
```suggestion
/-- The iff variation of `ascPochhammer_eval_neg_coe_nat_of_lt` for an integral domain. -/
theorem ascPochhammer_eval_eq_zero_iff [IsDomain R]
```

You should be able to golf this using [Polynomial.card_roots'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Polynomial/Roots.html#Polynomial.card_roots') and [ascPochhammer_natDegree](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Polynomial/Pochhammer.html#ascPochhammer_natDegree) but what you have is also fine.

After the changes above, this will become:
```suggestion
end Ring
```

Especially since we will eventually want to construct the analytic continuation, I think we should clarify as follows:
```suggestion

Note that this takes the junk value `0` outside the radius of convergence.
-/
```

```suggestion
theorem ordinaryHypergeometric_sum_eq (x : ùî∏) :
    (ordinaryHypergeometricSeries ùî∏ a b c).sum x =
      ‚àë' n : ‚Ñï, ((n !‚Åª¬π : ùïÇ) * (ascPochhammer ùïÇ n).eval a * (ascPochhammer ùïÇ n).eval b *
        ((ascPochhammer ùïÇ n).eval c)‚Åª¬π ) ‚Ä¢ x ^ n :=
```
(etc. several other examples below)

```suggestion
    (fun n => ordinaryHypergeometricSeries ùî∏ a b c n fun _ => x) =
      fun n => ((n !‚Åª¬π : ùïÇ) * (ascPochhammer ùïÇ n).eval a * (ascPochhammer ùïÇ n).eval b *
        ((ascPochhammer ùïÇ n).eval c)‚Åª¬π ) ‚Ä¢ x ^ n := by
```

Style nit: when line-length forces us to break a term over multiple lines, it is desirable to signal this with indentation:
```suggestion
    (ordinaryHypergeometricSeries ùî∏ a b c n fun _ => x) =
      ((n !‚Åª¬π : ùïÇ) * (ascPochhammer ùïÇ n).eval a * (ascPochhammer ùïÇ n).eval b *
        ((ascPochhammer ùïÇ n).eval c)‚Åª¬π ) ‚Ä¢ x ^ n := by
```

```suggestion
    (ordinaryHypergeometricSeries ùî∏ a b c n fun _ => 0) = Pi.single (f := fun _ => ùî∏) 0 1 n := by
```

This is a [non-terminal simp](https://leanprover-community.github.io/extras/simp.html#non-terminal-simps) so we should excise it. In this case, an alternative is:
```suggestion
  simp [ordinaryHypergeometricSeries, mul_assoc, mul_left_comm]
```

Optional:
```suggestion
  rcases habc with h | h | h <;>
  ext <;>
  simp [(ascPochhammer_eval_eq_zero_iff n _).2 ‚ü®k, h, hk‚ü©]
```
(though on second thought, what you have may in fact be better)
Yes, I think I prefer the original

It looks like `ùîπ` is a relic and can go:
```suggestion
variable {ùïÇ : Type*} (ùî∏ : Type*) [RCLike ùïÇ] [NormedDivisionRing ùî∏] [NormedAlgebra ùïÇ ùî∏] (a b c : ùïÇ)
```

As mentioned elsewhere, it's almost never desirable to have a hypothesis containing an equality. So we should spell this:
```suggestion
theorem ordinaryHypergeometric_radius_top_of_neg_nat‚ÇÅ {k : ‚Ñï} :
    (ordinaryHypergeometricSeries ùî∏ (-(k : ùïÇ)) b c).radius = ‚ä§ := by
  refine FormalMultilinearSeries.radius_eq_top_of_forall_image_add_eq_zero _ (1 + k) fun n ‚Ü¶ ?_
  exact ordinaryHypergeometricSeries_eq_zero_of_neg_nat (-(k : ùïÇ)) b c
    (Or.inl (neg_neg _).symm) (by omega)
```
and likewise below

If you add `open scoped Topology` higher up then you can use notation for `nhds`:
```suggestion
    Tendsto (fun (k:‚Ñï) ‚Ü¶ (a + k) / (b + k)) atTop (ùìù 1) := by
```

How about:
```suggestion
    ‚àÉ k < n, k = -a ‚à® k = -b ‚à® k = -c := by
```

You're creating a new type variable (carrying `Ring` typeclass) shadowing the old one. Instead you should just modify the explicitness of the existing `R` as follows:
```suggestion
variable {R}
```

I'm surprised you can use `have` like this. In any case `obtain` is more idiomatic here:
```suggestion
  ¬∑ obtain ‚ü®rn, hrn, rnn‚ü© := hrn
```

I realise the proof using the explicit `neg_neg` was part of a previous suggestion I made, but I now realise we can avoid grovelling around with these low-level terms by just using `aesop`:
```suggestion
  exact ordinaryHypergeometricSeries_eq_zero_of_neg_nat (-(k : ùïÇ)) b c (by aesop) (by omega)
```

```suggestion
  exact ordinaryHypergeometricSeries_eq_zero_of_neg_nat a b (-(k : ùïÇ)) (by aesop) (by omega)
```

Nitpick: redundant hypotheses:
```suggestion
      ‚àÉ k < n, k = -a ‚à® k = -b ‚à® k = -c := by
```

Again, let's lean on our tactics a bit more:
```suggestion
      ¬∑ simp [Nat.factorial_ne_zero] at hn
```

Style nit: I think it's more idiomatic to use `obtain` here:
```suggestion
        obtain ‚ü®kn, hkn, hn‚ü© := (ascPochhammer_eval_eq_zero_iff _ _).1 h
```

We like spaces (and don't need these parentheses):
```suggestion
    Tendsto (fun k : ‚Ñï ‚Ü¶ (a + k) / (b + k)) atTop (ùìù 1) := by
```
(also below in a few spots)

There's a nice tactic for this situation:
```suggestion
    field_simp [hx]
```

This lemma is useful enough to exist generally. I propose calling it:
```lean
theorem RCLike.tendsto_add_div_add_atTop_nhds_one (a b : ùïú) :
    Tendsto (fun k : ‚Ñï ‚Ü¶ (a + k) / (b + k)) atTop (ùìù 1) := by
```
and placing it just below `RCLike.tendsto_inverse_atTop_nhds_zero_nat` in `Mathlib.Analysis.SpecificLimits.RCLike`.
Yes I agree, another aim I have for the future is improve the api around cobounded limits, it doesn't really seem to exist, but that would take some work to do properly.

```suggestion
/-- The ratio of successive terms of the sum `ordinaryHypergeometric a b c r` is `r`. This theorem
```

`field_simp` is smart enough not to need these:
```suggestion
```

Style nit, we like spaces:
```suggestion
    Tendsto (fun k : ‚Ñï ‚Ü¶ (a + c * k) / (b + d * k)) atTop (ùìù (c / d)) := by
```

```suggestion
theorem RCLike.tendsto_add_mul_div_add_mul_atTop_nhds (a b c : ùïú) {d : ùïú} (hd : d ‚â† 0) :
```

```suggestion
/- Over an integral domain, the Pochhammer polynomial of degree `n` has roots at
`0`, `-1`, ..., `-(n - 1)` and nowhere else. -/
```

```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem ascPochhammer_eval_eq_zero_iff [IsDomain R]
```

```suggestion
```
~Is this an accidental suggestion?~ Retracted!

How about we call this:
```suggestion
theorem ofScalars_radius_eq_inv_of_tendsto [NormOneClass E] {r : NNReal} (hr : r ‚â† 0)
```
and then add the following convenience lemma below:
```lean
theorem ofScalars_radius_eq_of_tendsto [NormOneClass E] {r : NNReal} (hr : r ‚â† 0)
    (hc : Tendsto (fun n ‚Ü¶ ‚Äñc n‚Äñ / ‚Äñc n.succ‚Äñ) atTop (ùìù r)) :
      (ofScalars E c).radius = ENNReal.ofNNReal r := by
  suffices Tendsto (fun n ‚Ü¶ ‚Äñc n.succ‚Äñ / ‚Äñc n‚Äñ) atTop (ùìù r‚Åª¬π) by
    convert ofScalars_radius_eq_inv_of_tendsto E c (inv_ne_zero hr) this
    simp
  convert (continuousAt_inv‚ÇÄ <| NNReal.coe_ne_zero.mpr hr).tendsto.comp hc
  simp
```
(which should actually be better suited to your application)

```suggestion
This file contains API for analytic functions `‚àë c·µ¢ ‚Ä¢ x‚Å±` defined in terms of scalars
`c‚ÇÄ, c‚ÇÅ, c‚ÇÇ, ‚Ä¶`.

## Main definitions / results:
 * `FormalMultilinearSeries.ofScalars`: the formal power series `‚àë c·µ¢ ‚Ä¢ x‚Å±`.
 * `FormalMultilinearSeries.ofScalars_radius_eq_of_tendsto`: the ratio test for an analytic function
   defined in terms of a formal power series `‚àë c·µ¢ ‚Ä¢ x‚Å±`.
```
Just remarking that there might be a nice `calc` proof available for this (no action required unless you want).
Indeed there was, very clean!

We should follow the [Left of Colon](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html#hypotheses-left-of-colon) style here:
```suggestion
noncomputable abbrev ordinaryHypergeometricCoefficient (a b c : ùïÇ) (n : ‚Ñï) :=
  ((n !‚Åª¬π : ùïÇ) * (ascPochhammer ùïÇ n).eval a *
    (ascPochhammer ùïÇ n).eval b * ((ascPochhammer ùïÇ n).eval c)‚Åª¬π)
```

There's no need to work this hard (using `conv` and manual rewriting):
```suggestion
  have (k : ‚Ñï) : (a + k) * (b + k) * (c + k)‚Åª¬π * ((1 : ùïÇ) + k)‚Åª¬π =
      (a + k) / (c + k) * ((b + k) / (1 + k)) := by field_simp
  simp_rw [this]
```
I also think it's easier to read this.
The name here isn't right, but in any case I recommend inlining this lemma.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: define the ordinary hypergeometric function

Looking great, a few more nitpicks below:

> I agree with adding some more support for scalar Multilinear series, perhaps this could be extended to multiple types of maps and not just MkPiAlgebraFin?

I think `MkPiAlgebraFin` is special enough to deserve it's own dedicated API. If you have the appetite to write this as part of this PR and use it to implement the work here then that would be great. If not, I'm also OK with leaving things are they are for now and I'll do one final round of review after you've had a chance to react to my latest round of nitpicks.

I was having a look for adding API as you suggest, but I'm not entirely sure where it would lie. Ideally it would go in Mathlib\Analysis\Calculus\FormalMultilinearSeries.lean, but we really want to be able to use other results that come from other files such as Mathlib\Analysis\Analytic\Basic.lean and Mathlib\Analysis\NormedSpace\Multilinear\Basic.lean (I think). Perhaps this needs a new file?

> I was having a look for adding API as you suggest, but I'm not entirely sure where it would lie. [...] Perhaps this needs a new file?

Yes I think a new file would be the right move. Maybe `Mathlib.Analysis.Analytic.ScalarSeries` or `Mathlib.Analysis.Analytic.OfScalars` or ...

Thanks for all of this!

Please apply the remaining suggestions and then feel free to merge üéâ 

bors d+

:v: EdwardWatine can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
